issues.description: Images across the Domino's website and mobile app lack alternative text descriptions. Screen reader users encounter unlabeled images that provide no context, making visual content completely inaccessible to blind and low-vision users.
issues.evidence: Robles v. Domino's Pizza LLC (2019): Court found widespread missing alt text on images, violating WCAG 2.0 Level AA Success Criterion 1.1.1 (Non-text Content).

issues.description: Multiple hyperlinks on the site contain no accessible text content — they are either empty anchor elements or contain only non-text content without labels. Screen readers cannot announce the purpose of these links, making navigation impossible for assistive technology users.
issues.evidence: Court documentation identified empty links that screen readers could not interpret, violating WCAG 2.0 Level A Success Criterion 2.4.4 (Link Purpose).

issues.description: The pizza customization and ordering interface uses interactive elements that are not properly exposed to screen readers via ARIA roles and properties. Custom widgets for pizza size, toppings, and crust selection cannot be operated with assistive technology.
issues.evidence: Robles v. Domino's: Custom ordering widgets lacked proper ARIA roles, states, and properties, violating WCAG 2.0 Level A Success Criterion 4.1.2 (Name, Role, Value).

issues.description: The complete pizza ordering workflow — from menu browsing through customization to checkout — is fundamentally inaccessible to blind users. The plaintiff was unable to independently order food despite multiple attempts, as the entire flow relies on visual-only interactions without keyboard or screen reader support.
issues.evidence: Robles v. Domino's: Plaintiff Guillermo Robles, who is blind, could not order pizza through the website or app. The Ninth Circuit ruled the ADA applies to websites, and WCAG 2.0 AA is the applicable standard. Violates Success Criterion 2.1.1 (Keyboard).
